Con el crédito ADIM, pretende retomar también la venta de ropa, para solventar gastos durante su embarazo, pero sigue con sus compras de manzanas y uvas que las da a sus trabajadores.
texts.en:
Charling V. is 31 years old and sells apples and grapes in the neighborhoods of central Managua (the capital of Nicaragua). She began selling clothing upon order, but decided to quit that business in order to sell fruit.

At first, her sister supplied her with inventory to sell. When she started working with ADIM, she decided she should buy the fruit herself for distribution. She currently has people who sell and deliver the goods for her (she considers herself a capitalist), because she was pregnant at the time and had some difficulty moving around the place. Nonetheless, she still likes to go out and sell in order to generate extra revenue.

She buys boxes of apples and grapes from the Refrigerated Wholesale Market (a market where perishable goods can be bought in large quantities).

With her loan from ADIM, she intends to resume her clothing business so that she can pay her medical expenses related to her pregnancy. She continues her business of buying and selling apples and grapes, but she delegates the work to her employees.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing requested by customers

loans.name: Esna Nicida

texts.en:
Nicida is 42 years old and is married with two children. She has a business selling vegetables and other grocery items at the Bellavista Market, a massive, chaotic marketplace near the center of the city of Pucallpa, where she and her family live. Nicida also sells french fries, hot dogs and fried chicken from a cart in front of her home in the evenings.  Nicida’s husband is an entrepreneur with an independent business.

Nicida has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for three years and is a member of the communal bank “Virgen de la Natividad.”  She plans to invest this loan of 3,000 soles in purchasing vegetables, olives, oil, pasta and other products for sale.  

Nicida’s goal is to have a good amount of capital in order to expand her evening food sales business.

loans.use: To purchase food products to sell at the market

loans.name: Maria Atanacia

texts.es:
La señora María Atanacia V., esta muy agradecida por su cooperación en el anterior crédito el cual le servio para surtir su negocio, y con el cual a crecido bastante en las ventas.
Nueva mente está solicitando un préstamo para poder comprar más mercancía, porque la que tenia ya se le vendió y quiere nueva mente surtir el negocio ya que se su única fuente de ingreso ya que vive sola. 
Planea pagar este nuevo préstamo con los ingresos que generará el negocio con está inversión.
texts.en:
María Atanacia V. is very grateful for her previous loan, which allowed her to stock her business and for her sales to grow quite a bit. Once again she is requesting a loan to purchase more supplies because she has already sold what she had and she wants to stock her store again since it is her only source of income because she lives alone. She plans to pay this new loan with the income she will earn from investing in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Stock her business with more merchandise

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
Lilia C. is from the village of Tinotungan, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 48 years old. Lilia is married and has two adult children. To make a living, Lilia owns and operates a motorcycle transport service. Lilia has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month.

texts.en:
Celia is 41 years old and is married with two children. Celia sells chickens. Her husband works as a security guard.  Celia and her family live in the city of Pucallpa. 

Celia has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for six years and is a member of the communal bank “Virgen de la Natividad.”  She plans to use this loan of 2,000 soles (about $660) to purchase chickens for sale.  

Celia feels that Manuela Ramos has helped her very much by providing capital with which to finance her business.  Celia also feels that the organization has helped her to learn and develop more as a person through the educational and life planning sessions given by Manuela Ramos loan officers at the monthly meetings of her communal bank.

Celia’s goal is to eventually set up another business selling candies and grocery goods.

loans.name: Rafaela

texts.en: Rafaela V. is married to Peter and blessed with four children. She lives in the village of Dapaon Sindangan Zamboanga del Norte. She is a member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative, which helps her to obtain additional capital to earn more income that she may use for the education of her children. She started her business in 1996 by selling donuts in schools, offices and in the market area. She is thankful to Paglaum Cooperative for the support that allows her to meet her family's needs.

loans.use: Additional capital for snack vending

loans.name: Angel

texts.es: Ángel tiene 51 años, vive con su esposa Flor y sus hijos; Estefano de 14 y Mariela de 8, en su casa propia. Hace 6 años, decidió incursionar en un negocio propio debido a que acababa de perder su trabajo. Por tal motivo compró una máquina fotocopiadora para brindar este servicio a sus vecinos. Posteriormente tuvo la oportunidad de ingresar con su negocio a un colegio, por lo que compró otra fotocopiadora e implementó un pequeño kiosko de golosinas y bebidas. Ángel está muy contento por sus logros, pero aun así, consiguió otro trabajo como vigilante, donde se ocupa todas las mañanas. Entonces, su esposa atiende el kioko y su servicio de fotocopiado en el colegio por las mañanas y Ángel lo hace por las tardes, dejando a cargo de su hijo mayor la otra fotocopiadora que tienen en casa. De esta manera todos ponen de su parte para poder salir adelante, pues saben que unidos, con mucho empeño y dedicación lograrán sus objetivos. Es el sexto préstamo de Ángel con MFP y durante sus créditos anteriores siempre demostró ser muy responsable con los pagos. Con el dinero que ahora solicita comprará papel y útiles de escritorio para empezar a vender estos artículos, tanto en su casa, como en el colegio y así mejorar sus ganancias.
texts.en:
Ángel is 51 years old and lives with his wife, Flor, and his children, Estefano, 14, and Mariela, 8, in a home they own. Six years ago he decided to start up his own business because he was about to lose his job. For this reason he bought a photocopier to provide this service to his neighbors. Later he had the opportunity to take his business to a school, so he bough another photocopier and set up a small kiosk offering snacks and refreshments. Ángel is very pleased with his achievements, but even so he took another job as a security guard, which he does every morning. His wife then tends to the kiosk and copier at the school in the mornings, and Ángel does it in the afternoons, leaving his eldest child in charge of the copy machine he has at their home. In this way everyone does his or her part to help the family make headway because they know together, with a lot of hard work and dedication, they will achieve their goals. This is the sixth loan for Ángel with Kiva partner MFP, and during his previous loans he has always shown himself to be very responsible with his payments. With the money he is requesting, he plans to purchase paper and office supplies so he can start selling those items in both his home and at the school, and thus increase his profits.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase paper and office supplies

loans.name: Aristides

texts.es: Arístides tiene 51 años, vive con su esposo de 55 y su hijo Jaime de 15 años de edad, en su casa propia. Desde hace 3 años se dedica a la venta de comida y golosinas en un paradero de carros de transporte público en el distrito de Comas, en la ciudad de Lima. A Arístides siempre le ha gustado la cocina, es por eso que cuando decidió tener un negocio propio no dudo en elegir un puesto de comida, aunque muchas veces no se abastece para atender a toda su clientela. Pero ella está muy contenta por tener un negocio que la hace sentir independiente y útil en su hogar, ya que el sueldo de chofer de su esposo algunas veces no les alcanza para todos los gastos. Para un futuro cercano, Arístides quiere hacer crecer su negocio y más adelante tener un restaurante, espera poder realizar estos anhelos con muchas ganas y esfuerzo. Este es su segundo préstamo con MFP, ella se caracteriza entre los integrantes de su grupo por ser muy responsable en todos sus pagos. Con el dinero que viene solicitando comprará sacos de arroz y otros comestibles para incrementar el número de porciones de comida que vende en su puesto.
texts.en:
Arístides is 51 years old and lives with her husband, age 55, and her son Jaime, 15, in their own home. For the past three years she has made a living selling food and snacks at a public transportation parking lot in the district of Comas, in the city of Lima. Arístides has always enjoyed cooking, and that's why she decided to start her own business. She had no hesitation in choosing a food stand, although many times she did not have enough to tend to all her customers. She is very please with having the business and it makes her feel independent and useful in her home since her husband's chauffeur salary sometimes isn't enough to cover all their expenses. Arístides wants to keep growing her business in the near term, and later on she wants to have a restaurant. She hopes to reach these goals with a lot of desire and hard work. This is her second loan with Kiva partner MFP, and she has stood out among the members as being very responsible with her payments. With the money she is requesting she plans to purchase sacks of rice and other food products to increase the number of foods she sells at her post.

Translated from Spanish by Marty Greenstein, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase food to sell at her post

loans.name: Judith

texts.es: Judith tiene 27 años, vive con su pareja, Cristian (28 años) quien es chofer, y con sus hijos: Piero de 9, Marícelo de 4 y Jamir de 1 año de edad, en su casa propia. Desde hace un año se dedica a la venta de salchipapas (papas y salchichas fritas) afuera de su casa, pues esta actividad le permite tener independencia económica y apoyar a su esposo con los gastos del hogar. Debido a que él es chofer y trabaja durante casi todo el día, Judith debe afrontar el cuidado de sus hijos, lo cual realiza por las mañanas, y su trabajo a partir de las 6 de la tarde hasta las 10 de la noche. A Judith le gusta mucho su negocio porque siempre le gustó cocinar, lo único que no le gusta es tener que dejar a sus hijos solos dentro de la casa durante este tiempo, pues está muy ajetreada con la atención de sus clientes. Su deseo a futuro es tener una tienda en su misma casa donde pueda trabajar con mayor comodidad. Este es su sexto préstamo con MFP, ella es una persona muy estricta a la hora de cumplir con sus pagos, al igual que el resto de integrantes de su grupo, con el cual se siente muy contenta, porque todos son buenos amigos. Con el dinero que viene solicitando comprará mayor cantidad de papa, litros de aceite y otros ingredientes para aumentar las porciones de salchipapa que vende.

loans.use: Compra de comestibles e ingredientes para sus comidas

loans.name: Marina

texts.es: Marina tiene 37 años, vive con su esposo, Esteban, y sus hijos Alex de 13, Yoiri de 6 y Brigitte de 2 años y medio, todos viven en su casa propia. Ella se dedica a la venta de comida como postres, empanadas, salchipapas, caldo de pollo y otros, en un pequeño puesto que tiene en el mercado Jerusalén, uno de los más conocidos de su distrito. Su esposo Esteban también trabaja, pero no tiene una actividad fija, es por ello que la labor que realiza Marina es muy importante para su hogar. Adicionalmente a su puesto de comida, también vende muñecas y hace manualidades para lograr ingresos extras, por ello Marina atiende a su clientela muy bien, ganándose muchos amigos y nuevos clientes, lo cual es la parte más bonita de su trabajo. Marina ya tiene 17 años en este negocio y quiere seguir mejorando, pues su deseo a futuro es tener un restaurante especializado en pollo a la brasa, aunque sabe que soñar es bueno, piensa que aún le falta mucho camino por recorrer. Este es su 13avo préstamo con MFP y en sus créditos anteriores siempre ha caracterizado por ser muy puntual con todos sus pagos. Con el dinero que viene solicitando comprará sacos de arroz, fideos, papas y otros ingredientes para elaborar sus diferentes comidas.
texts.en:
Marina is 37 years old and lives in her own house with her husband Estaban, and their children Alex (13), Yoiri (6) and Brigitte (2). For a living, she sells food such as deserts, empanadas, “salchipapas”, and chicken soup at a small stand that she has in the Jerusalén market, one of the most well known in her district. Her husband Esteban also works, but he doesn’t have a fixed job which is why Marina’s work is so important to the household. In addition, at her food stand, she sells dolls and makes handicrafts to earn extra income. Marina is attentive to her customers and has gained many friends and new customers, which is the best part of her work. Marina has been in this business for 17 years and wants to continue to progress. Her future desire is to have a restaurant which specializes in barbecued chicken. Although she knows it is good to dream, she thinks that there is a long road ahead of her before she gets there. This is her 13th loan with MFP and her previous payments have always been characterized by punctuality. With the money she is asking, she will buy rice, noodles, potatoes and other ingredients to make different foods.

Translated from Spanish by Emma Felten, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: the purchase of provisions and ingredients for meals

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

location.town: Sto. Niño, Tukuran, Zamboanga del Sur

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Rosa tiene 33 años, vive con su esposo, quien trabaja en las minas y sus hijas: Lucero de 14, Katherine de 7 y  Carolina de un año y medio, en su casa propia. Desde hace 2 años se dedica a la venta de ropa por pedido, actividad que es un soporte para su familia, ya que muchas veces el sueldo de su esposo no es suficiente para todos los gastos del hogar. Es por ello que Rosa se siente feliz, pues se siente independiente y de utilidad para el desarrollo de su familia. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es que visita a sus vecinas y amigas y de paso va vendiendo su mercadería, aunque muchas veces algunas de sus clientas se demoran en los pagos y tiene que visitarlas muy frecuentemente. Pero con la experiencia, ya está manejando este aspecto mucho mejor, por lo que ahora sus ventas son muy rentables. En un futuro Rosa quisiera tener una tienda grande donde pueda ofrecer su mercadería, pero lamentablemente la zona en la que vive aun no es muy comercial. Este es su sexto préstamo con MFP, siempre ha sido muy puntual con todas sus cuotas, al igual que todo su grupo, el cual es muy estricto a la hora de los pagos. Con el dinero que viene solicitando comprará mayor cantidad de ropa para aumentar sus ventas y así mejorar la calidad de vida de su familia.

loans.use: Incremento de mercadería

loans.name: Laura

texts.en:
Laura is 41 years old and is married with four children.  Laura and her husband run a discotheque called “Pili’s.”  Laura also has a business selling cooked foods typical of the region in front of her home in the evenings. Laura’s husband is an environmental engineer specializing in forestry. Laura helped pay for him to get his degree. Because he could not find work in his chosen field, Laura’s husband now dedicates himself full time to running the bar/discotheque that the family owns next door to their home.

Laura has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for ten years and is a member of the communal bank “Virgen de la Natividad.”  She plans to invest this loan of 2,000 soles in her family’s discotheque as well as in her food sales business.  

Laura’s goal is to eventually have her own restaurant offering typical regional dishes.

loans.use: Products for a small home-based restaurant business; drinks and other items to sell at a discoteque.

loans.name: Tania

texts.es: Tania tiene 36 años, vive con su esposo Luis, quien es chofer, y sus hijos: Fabricio de 25, Sandra de 13 y Astrid de 24 días de nacida. Desde hace 8 años se dedica a la venta de productos de belleza a domicilio, actividad que le da el dinero necesario para apoyar con las necesidades del hogar. Pues como los ingresos de su esposo no logran cubrir todos los gastos, Tania trabaja para obtener ganancias adicionales. Si bien tiene que dedicar tiempo a sus hijos y trabajar, este negocio se lo permite, pues luego de realizar las labores domésticas sale a visitar a sus vecinas, amigas o familiares a ofrecer su mercadería. Tania compra gran cantidad de productos, en especial los que están en oferta y luego los vende a su precio real, es así que gana un buen porcentaje de la venta. Hasta ahora le está yendo bien en su negocio, por lo que desea perfeccionar más su metodología de venta. Este es su tercer préstamo con MFP y en sus créditos anteriores ha demostrado ser muy puntual con los pagos, ya que los invierte correctamente. Con el dinero solicitado comprará mayor cantidad de mercadería para tenerla en stock, además ayudará a pagar la reparación del carro de su esposo, ya  que necesita llantas nuevas y actualizar el seguro obligatorio.

loans.use: Incremento de mercadería y reparación del carro de su esposo

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

She decided to join PMPC because she knows that this is a good opportunity for her to put some additional capital into her business retailing candles. She deeply hopes that this opportunity can help to grow her business someday.

Luzviminda R. operates a small grocery store in their house that sells basic commodities. She is married to Nichomedes and blessed with one child. She is applying for a loan in order to augment her working capital in her sari-sari store at the same time helping her husband in accumulating income to support their family.

She is a new member in the cooperative and really shows her willingness to cooperative activities. She establishes good credit record in their community.

loans.name: Pepita

texts.en: Pepita is 57 years old and manages a general store and a hog-raising business in their village.  Pepita is so thankful for being part of Kiva where she is given the chance to develop her business and now, she is again hoping to take out a loan from Kiva lenders for the improvement of her store. She wants to request the amount of PHP 10,000 as additional capital to buy additional inventory for her store.  She hopes that like her hog raising, her store will also grow successfully in the future to be able to help her attain all her goals in life.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en:
Lucena is 52 years old. She is married to Perfecto and they are working hand in hand to uplift their poor living conditions in their village in Villa Gamiao, San Mateo, Isabela. They want to provide their children with their needs and especially to support their education. This is the reason why they keep on working hard to meet the growing needs of their family.

Lucena raises native chickens as her source of income. Her business has been of big help in the family. Her husband, on the other hand is doing farm activities in their village. Lucena wants to take out a loan from Kiva lenders amounting to PHP 11,000 for the improvement of her poultry business. She is hoping that through the loan, she will also be able to buy a piglet that she can start to raise. Lucena is working very hard and patiently, doing her best to become successful in her poultry-raising business.

loans.use: Business Improvement

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
Amelia Cocepcion is a responsible mother in Brgy. Almaguer South, Bambang, Nueva Vizcaya. She is married to Elias and they are blessed with two children: Aries and Abel. The eldest is in college and the youngest is in high school. Amelia and Elias want them to finish their college studies so that they will find stable jobs someday.

The couple helps one another to overcome the hardships and difficulties in life. They are both farmers which is their major source of income and their crops are rice and vegetables.

They earn an average net income of PHP 12,000 per harvest season which they use to meet their daily needs and to finance the tuition fees and allowances of their children. For the continuous maintenance of their farm, Amelia is now applying for a loan of PHP 6,000 to purchase fertilizers and pesticides for their farm. She believes that someday their children will finish their studies and improve their status of living.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and pesticides

loans.name: Solidad

texts.en:
“Doing something better is producing a bundle of success”, this is the guiding principle of Solidad, a resident of Cutog Grande, Reina Mercedes, Isabela. For the past eight months, she has managed a general store in their village. According to her, she earns a weekly net income of PHP 1,200.00 that she uses as rolling capital for her business. She hopes for continuous growth for her store and is asking for a loan of PHP 5,000.00 from Kiva lenders. She is hoping that her loan will be granted.

Solidad is 59-years old. She is married to Nicolas and they are blessed with nine children. The couple is happy from the blessings that they are receiving. Four of her children are already married, some are working and others are still dependent on them. Solidad is working hard, is determined to provide a better life for her family and to save for their needs as they grow older.

loans.use: To provide additional capital

loans.name: Jovie

texts.en:
Jovie brought success to her family for being productive in her 'sari-sari' store (community-based store) in their village of Cutog Grande Reina Mercedes, Isabela. She has been operating her store for seven years and she is making a weekly net income of PHP 1,000 which she uses as rolling capital and for the school expenses of her children.

Jovie wants to improve her business and so she would like to borrow additional capital from Kiva lenders in the amount of PHP 5,000. She hopes that the loan will give her a bigger chance to have a progressive business.

Jovie is 26 years old and married to Bonifacio, a farmer. They are blessed with four children: Angelica - 11 years old, already in grade school; Erica - 8 years old; Johny Vic - 4 years old, and their youngest is Mariel - 2 years old. Jovie hopes to give all her children a better education that will somehow lift them from poverty.

loans.use: Additional Capital

loans.name: Jay

texts.en:
Jay J. is from the village of Layawan, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old. Jay is single and has one school-age child. To make a living, Jay operates a business preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Jay has been in business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2008, Jay joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Jay has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Jay is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make food items for sale. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Jay from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her family's general living conditions. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Arminda

texts.en:
Arminda P., 55, has been a widow for years but lives her life to the fullest. She lives in Parola, Tondo, Manila with her 2 adult children who are already both working.

Arminda owns and manages a restaurant near the dockyards of Manila International Containers Terminal (MICT). She likes working at the restaurant hands-on because she gets to meet a lot of people. She earns a net income of P 60,000 a month. What really makes her proud about being in business is her ability to employ other people. Her restaurant has three assistants.

Since joining the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2007, Arminda has learned the value of saving for the future. Just recently, Arminda ventured into shipping bananas from Davao which she delivers to fruit vendors in the nearby market. She has found this business to be very rewarding, considering her restaurant’s location near the seaport.

Arminda needs a loan of P 50,000 as additional capital for her new venture, shipment of bananas. She also wishes to open another restaurant in another area.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: additional capital for banana shipping (new business venture)

loans.name: Rene Antonio

texts.es: Rene Antonio M. C. de 40 años de edad, reside en Ilopango, Departamento de San Salvador. Vive junto a su esposa, la cual se dedica a los quehaceres del hogar y sus tres hijos menores de edad, los cuales asisten a la escuela de Ilopango. Rene se dedica a la extracción de piedras en su propia mina, la cual también esta ubicada en el municipio de Ilopango. El solícita un préstamo, ya que desea  mejorar sus negocio y así obtener el dinero para la compra de dinamita y otras herramientas que se utilizan para la extracción de piedras en las minas.
texts.en:
Rene Antonio M. C. is 40 years old and lives in Ilopango, which is in the District of San Salvador. He lives with his wife, who takes charge of the household chores and the care of their three school-aged children who attend classes in Ilopango. Rene extracts stones from his own mine, which is also located in the town of Ilopango.

He is requesting a loan in order to improve his business. He plans to buy dynamite and other tools needed to extract stone from his mines.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase dynamite & tools for extracting stones from a mine

Ana Elizabeth posee una pupusería en su propia casa y ella se encarga de elaborar y vender las pupusas. Este es un negocio muy rentable, ya que las pupusas son un platillo típico salvadoreño el cual se vende mucho. Ella solicita un préstamo con el deseo de mejorar su negocio y lograr mayores ventas, el dinero obtenido lo utilizara para comprar todo los productos para la elaboración de las pupusas, tales como maíz, frijoles, chicharrón, entre otros productos más.

Hopefully, she will be able to earn bigger income after receiving a loan in CEVI. The interest rate is only 2% and she said, she could definitely repay what she owes.

Cynthia would like to ask for a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. With this loan, she will be able to buy pig feed and piglets and grow her business even more.

She is hoping that she will have a good return on her investment in her CEVI loan. She likes CEVI so much because it charges only a small interest rate of 2% a month, which is very low.

loans.name: Nora

texts.en:
Nora L., 42, lives in the town of Silang in the southern part of the upland Cavite province. Her husband Zosimo is a farmer. They have three adult children.

Nora is in the business of swine fattening and buying and selling fresh pork meat. She buys baby pigs and takes care of them in a pig pen until they grow and are ready for slaughter. She has been doing this for eight years and has found it to be very rewarding. She makes a profit of P6,000 per month. Before her pigs are ready for slaughter, she buys fresh meat from other farms which she retails to customers.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative four years ago. Her previous loans from the cooperative were used to improve their farm, especially their pig pen.

Her profits were used to purchase fertilizers and to pay for her children’s education. She wants all of her children to finish their studies, so she and her husband are working very hard, hand-in-hand.

Nora needs a loan of P12,000 to purchase commercial swine feeds and other farm supplies.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase commercial swine feed and other farm supplies

loans.name: Bella

texts.en:
Four years ago, Bella started having her own business. She joined ASHI then to be able to loan for a business capital which she used for starting up her hog fattening business and to be able to finance her manicure and pedicure business which she learned when she was six years old. Having her own business, her husband's sporadic income being a farm laborer will be augmented to be able to meet the daily needs of their three children who were in school. Sometimes Bella sells food in their neighborhood for n additional income because profit from her businesses alone can not supply the increasing demand of her family. Her eldest child, 21 years old hadn't even graduated from high school and her second child, 19 years had only graduated from elementary. It was a many years ago that Bella's two elder children stopped from going to school. During those years, Bella was not yet a member of ASHI and didn't have her own business. Now, through she requests from ASHI, she will be able to enhance her businesses to be able to finance the education of her nine year old youngest child until graduation in college. 
Presently, Bella requests for a much larger loan to be used in growing her hog fattening business (pig raising) and to be able to purchase a manicuring set to be able to generate daily income. Hog fattening business grows fast given enough business capital since the profit from it is as much double the amount of it capital after four months of fattening the pigs. Selling hogs in larger volume would really generate bigger profit. This is what Bella looks for in every loan she requests.

loans.use: Will be used for financing a hog fattening (pig raising) and manicure/pedicure businesses.

texts.en:
Hellen K. is 34 years old and married to Vitalis. They have three children. Her dairy business is located in Chembulet along Iten-Eldoret road in Eldoret Town. She has been in the dairy business for the past three years now.

She was introduced to KADET by a member and with the loan she has borrowed from KADET, she intends to buy animal feeds for her dairy cattle. In the future she intends to grow her dairy business and be able to supply milk to Kenya Cooperative Creameries (KCC).

Hellen intends to open a wholesale business and be able to pay school fees for her children.

About KADET:

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions in communities across Kenya.

loans.use: To buy animal feeds for her dairy cattle

loans.name: Eda

texts.en:
Eda C. and her husband, Crispeno, started a hog fattening and fruit tray weaving business four years ago. These businesses evolved from raising one piglet and selling fish! Though profit from their businesses is fairly good, Eda needs help growing her business since all of her family's daily expenses, including expenses for the education of her children, need to be covered.

To be able to accomplish her goal of increasing her profit, Eda decided to joining ASHI in 2007. The loans she requested then have been used to finance her hog and fish businesses. Eda has had two previous loans. However the growth she is dreaming of has yet to be reached, and she needs more business capital. She is now requesting a much larger amount to be able to buy more piglets and to finance a business weaving fruit trays using twigs. With these businesses, Eda hopes to be able to have more savings to help with her dream of buying a motorcycle to be used by her husband to sell fish. With her income, Eda is hoping to send all her children to college and have them graduate and have good careers.

loans.use: To finance a pig raising and fruit tray weaving business

texts.en:

loans.name: Josefa

texts.en:
Josefa A. is from the village of Upper Centro, Tudela,Misamis Occidental. She is 64 years old. Josefa is widowed and has 1 adult-aged children. To make a living, Josefa owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector selling home products. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling variety home products to local community members. Josefa has been engaged in her business for over 1 year and earns approximately 1,500.00 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Josefa joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josefa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000.00 PHP from PMPC. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Josefa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 3rd loan taken out by Josefa from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income.

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

loans.name: Edelyn

texts.en:
Mrs. Edelyn Tresuelo T. has been a resident of Prk. Ice Plant, Brgy. Sebucao, San Enrique, Negros Occidental since birth. She is now 42 years old and is married to Teodoro T. who works as a baker in one of the bakeries in Bacolod City. They had 3 daughters but unfortunately one died because of an illness.

She joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2004 and had her first PHP 3,000 loan which she used as additional capital in her food vending business. But the main purpose for why she joined was the insurance coverage that all NWTF-Project Dungganon members enjoyed - she knew that her family would benefit from such coverage.

Edelyn knew how precious such security would be to her family because at the time that she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon, she was already burdened with the health problems of her youngest child. The hardship and heartache she experienced with her child's medical difficulties did not hinder her from exerting more energy to sustain her food vending business. Instead it gave her the strength to continue moving on for she knew that NWTF-Project Dungganon would be her only refuge in her mission to improve her family's standard of living. Sometime in 2006, in spite of their best efforts, her youngest daughter died as a result of her lingering illness and the family was left deep in debt. But, Edelyn still remained active with the loan with no delayed payments.

Years later, when she could borrow a bigger loan, she decided to venture into a different business activity. That is when she started her "Sari-sari," or general store business. With the help of her Dungganon loans, her businesses enabled her to buy and renovate the house they were living in, which she was only renting before, have water connected to it, buy furnishings and appliances, and send her 2 surviving children to college. In the 6 years that she has been a Project Dungganon member, Edelyn can proudly testify that NWTF not only helped her through all the hardships, but also continues with her on her journey as she walks away from poverty.

For her 11th loan, Edelyn is borrowing PHP 19,000 to continue expanding her business activities so that she can secure the future of her 2 surviving children and continue to improve the quality of life for her family.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the calling of not just of a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing the realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: Additional Capital for her Food Vending Business

loans.name: Judy

texts.en:
Judy is married and has two children. She lives in Githurai, which is a highly populated, very busy center with many businesses. She has been in the decoration sales and beauty cosmetics business for the last 9 years and her customers include middle and low income earners.

Judy has not borrowed from other sources, and this is her first loan with KADET. She wants to add more stock for her decorations and beauty shop, but she also wants to diversify and start other businesses. She intends to open an electronics shop and also sell some clothes.

She believes that diversifying with other businesses will increase her income.

loans.use: Purchase more beauty products, electronics, and clothes to sell

loans.name: Arselinda

texts.en:
Two years ago, Arselinda joined ASHI for a loan to start up a business of her own. At the age of 57 and with an unemployed husband, she needs to be productive to be able to support her two children, who do not have enough education and are 26 and 28. Before ASHI came into her life, Arselinda and her family succumbed to poverty. The income she had raising and selling goats wasn't enough for her to be able to finance her family's daily needs. Goat is not salable in the province and not as expensive when sold to people unless one has a large volume of goats for selling.

Through loans, she was empowered to start up another business fattening hogs in addition to her current business. This business gives her profits as much as double the capital. However, she wanted to request a much bigger loan to be able to grow her business further and to be able to make it more sustainable with larger profits. Arselinda also wants to reinvest her profits into opening a variety store in the next few years.

For her personal and family life, she wishes that she will be able to build a concrete house for better shelter.

loans.use: Will be used to finance a hog-fattening (pig-raising) business.

loans.name: Carmelita

texts.en:
Letecia Crescencio is 44 years old. She is a client of Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI) and lives on a small island in Boholnamed Suba. She is a fisherman and has six children. Although her eldest daughter is already married, her other children are still in school.

She requested a loan of Php 18,000 from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy fishing materials and a new boat. She plans to use this second boat to earn money ferrying passengers to and from their small island.

She is enthusiastic about CEVI and likes their interest rate, which is 2% a month.

loans.use: To buy fishing materials and a new boat to provide ferrying services.

loans.name: Racquel

texts.en:
Racquel E. is from the village of Mobod, Oroquieta City, Misamis Occidental. She is 37 years old, married and has four school-aged children. Racquel owns and runs a restaurant where she offers a variety of dishes to local customers. Racquel is just starting this business.

In 2008, Racquel joined GDMPC to gain access to its financial services. Racquel has successfully repaid a previous loan of 4000 PHP from GDMPC (this will be her third loan from GDMPC). Racquel is requesting a new loan of 10000 PHP which will be used to purchase more inventory and to have some working capital at hand. Her goal is to use all additional profits to improve her family’s living conditions.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

Carmelita Garcia is a 48-year old fish vendor on a small island, called "Suba", in Talibon Bohol. She has two children: a son and a daughter, who are both in high school.

With this loan, she will be able to buy more fish to resell, as well as a new boat. Her hope is for her children to have the opportunity to study whatever they want as they grow older.

loans.use: To buy more fish and a new boat.

loans.name: Merlyn

texts.en:
Merlyn T., 49, is a native of Iloilo but migrated to Manila years ago. She now lives in a village in Pasay City with her husband, Paterno, 48, a security guard.

For ten years now, Merlyn has been selling different fruits in season. In her free time, she engages herself in the direct selling of cosmetics and clothing. She makes PHP 16,000 net income a month from her businesses.

Merlyn joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006. She needs a loan of PHP 19,000 as additional capital for her business. She wishes to expand her business so she can help employ her neighbors.
 

About CCT

loans.name: Toir

texts.en:
Toir is married and has 5 children. He was unemployed without a way to sustain his family, so he looked for a way to start his own business to be able to face his costs. With much effort Toir initiated his own business with very little merchandise. Selling foodstuff, little by little he was able to maintain his home and start to grow his business, incorporating the sales of grocery items, and improving the quality of service he offered. Toir needs a loan of 8000 Somoni, which he will use to provide more foodstuff and continue to work hard to sustain his family. He and his family very much appreciate your support in helping them.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

With this loan, he will purchase fertilizers to use on his crops so that he can sell more produce at a higher price. loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Annabelle B., 33, hails from Silang, Cavite. Her 35-year-old husband, Danny, works for a private security agency.  They have three school-aged children.

Annabelle buys old cars and sells them with a little price mark-up after a few touches of new paint and other accessories. But she makes more earnings from her computer shop. She earns at least 20,000 Philippine pesos a month out of these combined businesses.  

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005. She started with only two personal computers. With loans from CCT, she now has five personal computers. She was also able to purchase two tricycle units from her profits.

Now on her 13th loan cycle, Annabelle needs a loan of P45,000 for the expansion of her business. She will buy additional computers for her computer shop. She also wants to try buying and selling motorbikes.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social-development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace F.'s loan from ASHI is a great support to her fisherman's husband and in his fishing business. A year after Grace's first loan from ASHI which she used for her fish selling, rice and food spices retailing business, she was able to request for another loan much larger than her first one to be used for her husband's fishing business. By then, they were able to purchase their own fishing boat. Grace fish selling business thereafter had grown. However, income and profits she makes are insufficient to cover all the expenses her family daily lives require in addition to her business capital requirement. Grace has to increase her profit by growing her businesses more to be able to send all of her three children who age from two to 19 to college until graduation. Therefore to be able to attain her aspiration Grace is requesting for another loan since she had paid up the whole she loaned previously. She wants to use her loan for another business which is hog fattening (pig raising) and financing her husband's fishing business to sell more fish. With hog fattening, profit is as much double than the amount of its capital. With this, Grace hopes to be able to purchase another fishing boat and to become a wholesaler of food spices in the market.

loans.use: Will be used to finance her husband's fishing business and hog fattening (pig  raising) business.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is a mother of two children who are 5 and 8 years old. She is married to Hector F., who earns his living as a rice-mill machine operator. To help her husband support their young family, Josephine cooks a variety of native delicacies, which she sells in the local school. This adds about 2,900 Philippine pesos to their family's monthly income.

For her 13th loan cycle, Josephine wants to borrow PHP 6,000 to add to her capital in her food-vending business so that she could save enough to have their house repaired.

In the picture, Josephine and her mother are packing the food products into single-serve plastic bags before she takes them to the local school to sell.

loans.name: Nova

texts.en:
Nova C., 35, is a young widow from a village called Pulong Saging (Banana Island) in Silang, Cavite. She lives with her three school-aged children.
 
Nova is in the business of buying and selling used cars. But it is her apartments that give her a steady monthly income, covering all their family’s basic needs, including the children’s education. She earns at least 50,000 Philippine pesos a month from seven apartment units, which only started out as two apartment units prior to her joining the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005.  

She was able to buy a second-hand car and was able to renovate her apartments out of her profits from the business. She has just finished repaying her previous loan with the cooperative and has applied for a new one in the amount of P47,000.  She needs the funds to complete the renovations of all of her seven apartment units to attract good renters.  

Nova believes in the value of education, that’s why she works hard to see her children finish their college education.

In her last loan, she borrowed 22,000 Philippine pesos, which she invested in the vulcanizing shop managed by her husband. It is now earning PHP 5,000 per month. This time around, she is planning to invest the PHP 22,000 she is borrowing to use as capital to buy and sell feeds in her general store as an additional source of  income.

texts.en:
Vilma B., 36, is a multi-skilled businesswoman who lives with her 3 children in Barrio Filipino, Don Carlos, Pasay City.  Her husband Hacer, 42, is a computer programmer.

She also rents out a room next to their house to transients/boarders.  Combined, from all  these businesses she earns at least P18, 000 net income a month.  

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2006.  She has been praying fervently for the restoration of her family which was almost ruined by a third party. She is thankful for the spiritual comfort the staff of the cooperative has provided her all these years.  

Vilma needs a new loan in the amount of P32, 000, which she will spread to all her businesses for expansion.  She has been planning to move to another place (Antipolo, Rizal) and venture into farming.  She also wishes to own a taxi or a jeepney someday.

Maria G.	Venta de comestibles


  Utilizan su crédito para  fomentar y variar la actividad que ya están realizando. Entre las mercaderías a ser compradas citamos: compra de insumos para la fabricación de comestibles (harina , carne,  aceite, huevos, condimentos) compra de leche azúcar, yerba, harina, sal panificados y verduras para su posterior venta, compra venta de bebidas como refrescos, gaseosas, cervezas, vinos, compra de artículos de ocasión como ropas, guantes, bufandas, gorras etc. redoblan esfuerzos tratando de mejorar sus ingresos y así poder ofrecer a sus hijos la posibilidad de acceder a una buena preparación académica y por consiguiente una buena opción laboral.
texts.en:
The “Renacer” committee is currently completing its fourth cycle. It’s members are already productive, which is why each one has developed her own microenterprise without major difficulties. The names of the members, together with their business activities, are as follows:

Cynthia A., making and sale of bed sheets Melania G., cosmetics sales Susana V., mini-mart Patricia R., mini-mart Rosalia S., laundry Angelina R., kiosk Nery R., sale of sausages Emilce P., sale of dry goods Maria P., clothing sales Felipa A., sale of various articles Carmen Z., kiosk Maria M., food sales Dionisia C., mini-mart Miriam Estela B., clothing sales Nilda Bolaño, food sales Cipriana S., dry-goods sales Gilda B., perfume sales Ramona R., food sales Myrian I., food sales Maria G., food sales

They will use their loan to promote and diversify the businesses that they have already established. The merchandise to be purchased includes: ingredients for making food (flour, meat, oil, eggs, condiments), milk, yerba, flour, salt, breads and vegetables for later sale, purchase of drinks such as soft drinks, soda water, beers, wines, purchase of second-hand goods such as clothing, gloves, scarves, caps, etc.

They are redoubling their efforts, trying to increase their income and, thus, offer their children the possibility of getting access to good academic preparation and, as a result, good options for work.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of ingredients for making food (flour, meat, oil, eggs, condiments), milk, yerba, flour, salt, breads and vegetables for later sale, purchase and sale of drinks such as  soft drinks, soda water, beers, wines, purchase of  second-hand goods such as clothing, gloves, scarves, caps, etc

loans.name: Fe Y Esperanza Group

texts.es:
Este comité se encuentra actualmente en su 10º ciclo cuenta con 17 integrantes. 
Las integrantes se dedican a actividades varias entre las que se destaca la venta de comestibles, bebidas, despensa, peluquería, además de venta de ropas, entre otras cosas el destino de los fondos va para la compra de materiales como telas, ropas, hilos, carne, aceite, verduras, entre otras cosas. El comité presenta buena relación interna y respeto entre sus integrantes. 
Entre sus metas inmediatas resaltan la necesidad de que sus hijos se formen académicamente y puedan optar por un buen empleo, es por eso que redoblan esfuerzos para poder darles los materiales que puedan posibilitar lograr sus objetivos. 

El comité “Fe y Esperanza” lleva trabajando con la con la Fundación Paraguaya más de 2 años por lo que la mayoría de sus integrantes ya tiene una actividad productiva en funcionamiento, por lo que el destino que las señoras darán a sus fondos será la compra de ingredientes por ejemplo: aceite, verduras, carne, arroz, harina para aquellas que se dedican a la venta de minutas así también frutas, refrescos, azúcar, vasitos de plástico, cucharitas, para las que se dedican a vender ensaladas de frutas, ropa y abrigos de temporada como gorros, guantes, medias, jeans, camisas, entre otras mercaderías de venta rápida en la temporada, frutas de temporada como banana, naranja, pomelo, mandarina, piña etc.
texts.en:
This committee is currently in its 10th cycle with 17 members.

The members work in various activities including those who excel at the sale of consumables and drinks, a pantry, a hair salon, as well clothing sales and others. The funds will be used to purchase materials such as fabrics, clothing, thread, meat, oil, vegetables and other things. The committee has good internal relations and respect amongst members.

Amongst their immediate goals, what stands out is the need to form their children academically so they can choose a good career. For this reason, they are doubling their efforts to give them the necessary materials to reach their goals.

The committee “Fe y Esperanza” (Faith and Hope) have been working with Fundación Paraguaya for more than two years so that the majority of their members are now operating in a productive occupation. Thus, the women that sell fast food will use the funds for the purchase of ingredients such as oil, vegetables, meat, rice, and flour while those that sell fruit salads will buy fruits, sodas, sugar, plastic cups and spoons. Other merchants will purchase clothes and seasonal wear like hats, gloves, socks, jeans, shirts, for sale in season and seasonal fruits like banana, orange, pomelo, mandarin, pineapple, etc…

Translated from Spanish by Rebecca Towle, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: for the purchase of ingredients such as oil, vegetables, meat, rice, and flour, fruits, sodas, sugar, plastic cups and spoons, clothes and seasonal wear like hats, gloves, socks, jeans, shirts, for sale in season and seasonal fruits like banana, orange, pomelo, mandarin, pineapple, etc…

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Commerce

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is 34 years old, married to Simion Kandie, who is a policemen, and they are blessed with six children. Her dairy business is located along Burar - Iten Road in Eldoret. She has been in the dairy business for the past four years.

Elizabeth was introduced to KADET by a client and, with the loan she has applied for, she intends to buy animal feed for her cattle. In the future, she intends to grow her dairy business to supply milk to Kenya Cooperative Creameries. She would also like to branch out into poultry farming and be able to buy a plot of land where she can build a residential house for her family. She wants to be able to send her children to higher institutions of learning.

About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions in communities across Kenya.

loans.use: To buy feed for dairy cattle

loans.name: Exaltacion

texts.en:
Exaltacion C. is 46 and lives in Malaking Tatyao, Silang, Cavite.  Her husband Reynaldo, also 46, is a driver.  They have six children, two of whom are already working.
Exaltacion manages a plant nursery, situated along the national highway, where she takes care and sells ornamental and flowering plants.  This business has been providing for her family for the last twenty years.  She earns P40, 000 a month.  
She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005 and has since been providing her the necessary assistance she needs for the continuity of her business.  She  just finished repaying her previous loan, which she used to buy wire mesh to fashion into trellises for their crawling plants.  From her profits, she was able to buy a washing machine for the family and a second-hand vehicle which she uses for plant deliveries,  and she was able to have their house renovated.
Exaltacion is applying for a new loan amounting to P24, 000.  She will use the funds to buy more plant seedlings, organic fertilizers and plant pots.  She hopes to put up another nursery in the next town soon.  


About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice.  This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context.  It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.  

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: plant seedlings, fertilizers and plant pots

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El presente comité se encuentra, en su octavo ciclo. Todas las integrantes de este comité realizan diversas actividades con el fin de poder ayudar con los ingresos de la casa. Las actividades que realizan cada señora son: 

Griselda N.T..	Venta de Frutas
Arminda A..	Venta de mercería
Silvia L. A..	costurera
Mara Luz C..	Peluquera
Cyntia M. A..	Venta de Ropas

Gladys T.-	Venta de frutas 
Antonia T..	Venta de cigarros
Mirna R..	Decoradora
Isabel G..	Venta de ropas
Ramona R..	Modista
Florentina B..	Venta de ropas
Andrea M. R..	Venta de Carbón
Clara R. S..	Venta de artículos de limpieza
Carmen C..	Peluquera
Raimunda C..	Venta de cosméticos 
Rocio G..	Venta de mercería
Jessica P. agüero.	Venta de mercería
	


El crédito solicitado será invertido en la compra de mercaderías tales como: (Especificar en este campo el uso de los fondos. Ejemplo: compra de cosméticos como labiales, cremas, shampoo, desodorantes, colonias etc., también telas, hilos, artículos de limpieza como: detergentes, frutas como: naranja, banana, piña, melón, manzana, pera, ropas varias como: remeras, short, camisillas, pantalón, pollera, toallas, pulsera,  collar, aros, anillos.
texts.en:
This group is in its eighth loan cycle. All of the members of this group are involved in different activities. Their goal is to be able to help with the household income. Each woman’s activity follows. Griselda N.T.. Sells Fruit Arminda A.. Sells Hardware Silvia L. A.. Seamstress Mara Luz C.. Hairdresser Cyntia M. A.. Sells Clothes Gladys T.- Sells Fruit Antonia T.. Sells Cigarettes Mirna R.. Decorator Isabel G.. Sells Clothes Ramona R.. Dressmaker Florentina B.. Sells Clothes Andrea M. R.. Sells Charcoal Clara R. S.. Sells Cleaning Supplies Carmen C.. Hairdresser Raimunda C.. Sells Cosmetics Rocio G.. Sells Hardware Jessica P. agüero. Sells Hardware The loan they are asking for is to buy various merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy various merchandise

loans.name: Sunita

texts.en:
Mrs. Sunita L. lives in a nuclear family with her husband and two children in Khogana Dobato. The majority of the people in this region are engaged in farming. Mrs. L. has one daughter and one son. Her daughter is studying in grade 5 and her son is in primary school. 

Mrs. L.'s husband, Lal Bahadur L., is a taxi driver who owns his own taxi. He drives his taxi in Kathmandu Valley. All the member of her family depends on her husband's income. Now Mrs. Sunita L. is requesting a loanof Rs 15000.00 to help her husband repair his taxi. 

Both Mrs. and Mr. L. want to provide a good education for their children. In Nepal, the cost of education is very high compared to earnings.

loans.use: To repair their taxi

loans.name: Salina Jerotich

texts.en:
Salina Jerotich is 46-years-old and she is married to Joseph Chebotich. They have been blessed with six children. Her retail business is located at Chembulet in Eldoret Town. She has been in the retail business for three years.

Salina was introduced to KADET by another client. She has applied for a loan that she intends to use to add more stock to her retail shop, such as sugar, rice, cooking fat, bar soap and other small things.

In the future, she intends to open a wholesale shop. She also hopes to diversify into poultry keeping, dairy farming and rental housing. This would increase her income base and enable her to educate her children further.


About KADET:
The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services in order to  relieve suffering and improve living conditions in communities across Kenya.

loans.use: Adding stock to her retail shop with things like sugar, soap, and cooking fat.

loans.name: Elenita

texts.en:
Elenita T., 47, has been buying and selling farm produce like bananas, sweet potatoes, tomatoes and other fruits and vegetables in season in her village in Silang, Cavite for six years. These agricultural products are abundant in her location.

Elenita earns P12,000 a month from buying and selling agricultural produce. Her three adult children take turns in assisting her, particularly in the transport of items she buys and sells from the farm to the market.

She joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2005 and has since been enjoying its many benefits for women entrepreneurs. Elenita has just finished repaying her previous loan from CCT and has applied for a new loan of P18,000.

She wants to have her house refurbished. Elenita also dreams of owning a tricycle (a motorcycle with sidecar) for easy transport of the agricultural produce she buys from the farms.

loans.use: Additional capital for her business / house repair

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en: Elizabeth   bakes cake and sells. She is 51 years old and married with 4 children. She has been in the business since 1981. She hopes for the loan amount of N100, 000 to purchase more baking material to sells. She says thanks to all KIVA lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more baking material

loans.name: Paul

texts.en: Paul sells phone accessories. He is 35 years old and single. He has been in the business for four years. He is hoping for a loan of N150,000 to purchase more phone accessories to sell. He says "thanks" to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more phone accessories to sell

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita Lama (Shakya) opened her gift shop two years ago in the village of Khogana Dobata, intending to raise the living standard of her family. She sells various types of gift and decorative items in her shop. In Nepal the demand for gift items is increasing constantly because Nepal is very rich in its festivals. So to meet the demand of the customers, Mrs. Anita Lama is requesting a loan in the amount of Rs 15000.00 to buy various types of gift items for her shop. 


Anita Lama lives in a nuclear family with her husband and two sons. Her husband's name is Rajesh Shakya. He went to Dubai few years ago for work. Her older son is studying in class 5 and her younger son is in primary school.

loans.use: to buys gift items for her shop

loans.name: Tamemsu Group

texts.en:
Here are the members of the Tamemsu group. They are small-scale business people and subsistence farmers from Massorie Village, which is about thirteen miles from Makeni. They have applied for a loan of Le 500,000 for each member. This will be their first loan from Kiva and SMT. With this loan, they will be able to improve their businesses so that sales and profit will also improve for them. The loan will help these people to look after themselves, feed and clothe their children, and pay their children's school fees. 

Jatu S. (left) is the leader of this group. Jatu is thirty years of age. She was born in a village called Maroki about seventeen miles from Makeni, but now lives in Masorie Village with her husband and four children. Jatu has one child in junior secondary school, two in primary school, and one that is too young for school. 

Jatu sells rice, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), groundnuts and clothing. With this loan, Jatu will buy eight barters of palm-oil (five gallons of palm-oil make a barter). Jatu buys the palm-oil in the villages surrounding Masorie Village at Le 50,000.00 per barter, and sells either in Makeni or in Freetown, he capital of Sierra Leone.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Djoma

texts.fr: Cette dame est mariée et mère de 02 enfants ; elle habite le quartier de Gbeyendi à Lomé. Elle a décidé cette année de se lancer dans la vente de pagnes de qualité pour aider financièrement son mari électricien, à s’occuper de l’éducation de leurs enfants. Elle a fait ce choix parce qu’elle avait appris la coiffure, mais elle n’a  pas pu ouvrir son atelier de coiffure faute de moyens. Elle sollicite donc un prêt de WAGES pour acheter 25 pièces de pagnes Super Wax, 20 pièces de pagnes Hitarget, 10 pièces Soso. Elle est convaincue qu’elle réussira dans son projet
texts.en:
This woman is married and the mother of 2 children. She lives in the neighborhood of Gbeyendi in Lomé. This year she decided to launch a business selling high quality "pagnes" (colorful wax cloths) in order to financially help her husband, an electrician, take care of the education of their children. She chose this business because having learned the skill of hairdressing, but she could not open her own hairdressing salon, due to lack of funds.

Therefore, she is requesting this loan in order to purchase 25 sets of "Super Wax" brand "pagnes", 20 sets of "Hitarget" brand "pagnes" and 10 sets of "Soso". She is convinced that she will succeed in this business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase high-quality "pagnes" (colorful wax cloth)

loans.name: Messanvi

texts.fr: Ce monsieur habite le quartier Bassadji à Lomé où il s’est spécialisé depuis 1993 dans la vente de pièces de rechanges automobiles. Cette activité lui permet de se prendre en charge et d’aider ses 02 petits frères à assurer leurs frais de scolarité. Actuellement il a besoin de renouveler son stock ; c’est pour cela qu’il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour acheter 08 amortisseurs, 10 cartons de bougie et 20 lampes. Ce prêt lui permettra aussi de couvrir ses frais de transport vers le Nigéria où il s’approvisionne. Cet homme est célibataire et sans enfants.
texts.en:
This gentleman lives in the neighborhood of Bassadji in Lomé, where since 1993 he has specialized in selling spare parts for automobiles. This business enables him to take care of his two younger brothers and pay for their school tuition.

Right now he needs to re-stock his products; it is for this reason that he is requesting a loan from WAGES (the micro-finance institution) to purchase 8 shock absorbers, 10 cartons of candles and 20 lamps. This will also enable him to pay for the cost of transport from Nigeria, where he supplies himself.

He is single and does not have children.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase spare-parts for cars

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is 48 years old and married with 4 children. She has been in the business of selling provisions for 8 years. She is requesting a loan in the amount of N 150,000 to purchase more provisions to sell. She says "thanks" to all the Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more provisions to sell.

loans.name: Mosherif

texts.ru: Мошериф Азимова проживает в районе Явана. Возраст 41 год. Вдова, имеет 3 детей.  Сын занимается ремонтом квартир. Сама Мошериф более 5 лет занимается торговлей. Торгует она одеждой у себя дома. Помимо этого она еще занимается животноводством. Кредит просит для закупа нового ассортимента. Покупает она с города, а потом продает в своем кишлаке.
texts.en:
Mosherif A. lives in the Yavan region. She is 41 years old. She is a widow and has three children. Her son remodels apartments. Mosherif herself has been in retail for more than five years. She sells clothing at her home. Besides that she also does animal husbandry. She is asking for a loan to buy a new assortment. She buys the items in the city and then resells in her village.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a new assortment

loans.name: Chona

texts.en:
Like many other enterprising housewives, Chona B., 37, of Maricaban, Pasay City, never has an idle day. Her husband, Danilo, 58, is a head chef in a middle class restaurant.

Chona owns and manages a sari-sari (general) store that she operates out of her house. They also have a few rooms which she rents out to transients and student boarders. Their newly acquired family van (shown in the picture) is also for hire. She earns at least P25,000.00 a month from these business activities.

Chona joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative in 2001. She is among the pioneer members of the cooperative in Pasay 1 and has just finished repaying her previous loan. She applied for a new loan in the amount of P30,000.00 to expand her business to include retailing women’s accessories.

Chona’s husband was an overseas contract worker but had to come home due to an illness. It has been Chona’s fervent prayer that he recuperates well so that he can still enjoy their happy marriage.

About CCT

The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines, in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: To purchase women's accessories for business expansion.

loans.name: Malaneh Group

texts.en:
Here are Members of the Malaneh group. They are small scale businesspeople in Massorie village which is about thirteen miles away from Makeni. They are small scale businesspeople and also subsistence farmers. They have applied for a loan of Le 500,000 for each for the first time from Kiva Lenders through SMT. With this loan; they will be able to improve their businesses so that sales and profit will also improve for them. In this way, these people can better look after themselves and children in terms of feeding, clothing and paying their school fees. 

 
Sullay F. (middle) is the leader of this group. Sullay is forty-seven years of age.  He was born in Masorie village which is thirteen miles away from Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. Sullay is married to a businesswoman; he is a father of seven children. Two of his children are not of school going age. Sullay plants cassavas, ground-nuts, rice and also owns a big palm-tree farm. He will invest this loan into his farm and also buy some gallons of palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil) to sell. Sullay has been a businessman and a farmer for more than thirty years now.

loans.use: Invest in his business

loans.name: Shamsiya

texts.ru: Шамсия Азимова проживает в районе Явана. Возраст 46 лет. Замужем, имеет 5 детей. Муж работает в одной из местных фирм. Сама Шамсия более 3 лет занимается животноводством. Она покупает подешевле с районов, а потом в центре продает подороже. Кредит просит для заупа скота.
texts.en:
46-year-old Shamsiya A. lives in the Yavana district with her husband and five children. Her husband works in one of the community firms. Shamsiya has been engaged by herself in raising animals for more than three years. She buys them cheaply around the region, and then sells in the center at a profit. The loan request is to purchase livestock.

Translated from Russian by JD Bergeron, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase livestock

loans.name: Djeynaba

texts.fr: djeynaba S. est un parent bénéficiaire spécialisée dans le petit commerce de produits pour enfants et surtout dans les produits saisonniers(mangues).elle a une expérience de plus de dix ans dans son activité.elle assiste beaucoup son mari dans la gestion de la dépense quotidienne.par conséquent elle sollicite un crédit de cinquante mille(50 000)frs pour augmenter son fond et mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Djeynaba S. is a recipient parent specialized in small-scale commerce in children’s merchandise and especially in seasonal goods (mangoes). She has over ten years of experience in her work. She helps her husband very much with managing day-to-day expenses. Consequently, she’s requesting a loan of 50,000 francs to increase her working capital and to satisfy her customers better.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Commerce

loans.name: John Igwe

texts.fr: Cet homme est marié et habite le quartier de Bè Kpéhénou à Lomé. Depuis 1998, il a pu trouver un marché très rentable de la vente des sacs de friperie. Ce commerce lui permet surtout de se prendre en charge et de lancer des commandes de bals de sacs en provenance d’Italie. Pour réceptionner un nouveau stock, il sollicite un crédit de WAGES pour lancer une nouvelle commande de 25 bals de friperie. Il compte beaucoup sur sa longue expérience pour rembourser ce prêt. Cet homme n’a pas d’enfant.
texts.en:
This man is married and lives in the Bè Kpéhénou neighbourhood of Lomé. Since 1998, he has found a very profitable market for secondhand bags. This business allows him, above all, to support himself and to order bags from Italy. He is requesting a loan to order a new stock of 25 bales of used merchandise. He is counting on his extensive experience to repay this loan. This man does not have any children.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy used bags

loans.name: Rc Mabai Rowala Primary School Group

texts.en:
These are teachers of the RC Mabai Rowala Primary School in the town of Magburaka. The school was built by Roman Catholics in 1968 and is now made up of six staff and 254 pupils.

This is the school's first loan from Kiva through SMT. With this loan, some members of staff will start a small business and those who are already running small businesses will reinvest the funds into their existing businesses. Other staff members will be using the loan to buy pieces of furniture, to fund home building projects, and to pay for education - either for themselves or their children.

Alpha S. S. (left) is the leader of this group and has been the Head Teacher at the school for ten years now. He was born in a village call Massessebeh, about thirteen miles from Makeni city, in northern Sierra Leone. He is married with eight children – one of his children is already on his own, two are still in primary school and five are in secondary school. Mr. S. will use this loan to buy house building materials.

loans.use: To buy house building materials.

loans.name: Yrubek

texts.ru: Бахронов Урубек проживает в районе Явана. Возраст 60 лет. Женат, имеет 4 детей. Ярубек более 30 лет занимается предоставлением услуги "такси". Вот некотрое время работает на "Рогунской" электростанции. Кредит просит для ремонта автомашины, т.к. этот вид услуги тоже является источником дохода. Ярубек копит деньги, т.к. хочет сыграть свадьбу сына.

loans.use: Ремонт автомашины

loans.name: Luis

texts.en:
Luis C., 46, lives in Pasay City with his wife Gemma, 41, a community organizer, and their four school-aged children. Luis owns and manages a sari-sari (general) store which he started last year, the same time he joined the Center for Community Transformation (CCT) Credit Cooperative. His previous loans have been helpful in the continuous growth of his business. In addition, he now sells electronic load credits for mobile phones. He makes more than P30,000.00 a month from this business.

Luis uses his profits for the family’s daily basic needs and his children’s education. He wants them all to receive college educations, believing that proper education could get them out of poverty. Luis is requesting a loan of P25,000.00 for the expansion of his business.

About CCT The Center for Community Transformation (CCT) is an organized Christian response against poverty and social injustice. This is carried out through the fusion of social development initiatives and evangelical mission in a uniquely Filipino context. It serves urban and rural poor communities throughout the Philippines in pursuit of its desire to see changed lives, strong families, and transformed communities centered in the Lordship of Jesus Christ.

CCT is a member of the Five Talents family.

loans.use: Additional capital for business expansion

loans.name: Ousmah

texts.fr: Ce monsieur est un spécialiste de la broderie, plus précisément il est styliste modéliste. Il a beaucoup de clients dont la plupart viennent du Mali et du Sénégal. Il confectionne de bons habits brodés à ses clients. Il est aussi très visité par les clients togolais du quartier Bassadji. Il est marié et cette acticité lui permet de couvrir tous les besoins de ses 04 enfants. Actuellement il a besoin d’acheter une nouvelle machine à broder pour pouvoir élargir ses activités. Il veut aussi acheter 04 rouleaux de fils à coudre ; c’est pour cette raison qu’il demande un crédit de WAGES
texts.en:
This gentleman is a specialist in embroidering. He is a stylist and pattern designer to be exact. He has many customers, most of whom come from Mali and from Senegal. He makes nice embroidered clothing for his customers. He is also much visited by Togolese customers from the Bassadji district.
